Content-Type: text/plain;

Tucson looks to Optimus as he's bathed in the fire.  Yet, instead of chargi=
ng in as the others would have thought he'd do, Tucson remains put and in a=
 train of quiet thought.  So much so that he gave such an emotionless gaze =
as if in deep meditation.  Yoketron had taught him not to act in complex si=
tuations but to think instead, of a way to cleverly get around a tough spot=
.

He looks at the fungi growing in the cavern, and the stalagmites and sta=
lactites and sniffs the moisture rich air around them.

"Water.  It feeds t=
he plants and ground even this far down.  Fire, as powerful as it is, it ye=
t has one weakness.  And what gives life to the vegetation, brings death to=
 the flames of fire.  And even more so of an enemy to flames is the cold ea=
rth that is beneath our feet.  But we haven't got time to dig, we need wate=
r and I sense it, all around us.  If we can access the water we can put out=
 the fire."


Don't be envious of what you don't have, be grateful for thin=
gs you already posses.  Nothing is worth more than family and friends.

On =
Jan 18, 2012, at 12:26 PM, Super Cyclonus <supercyclonus@...> wrote:
=

> > <OLD>
> >
> > Tucson had a feeling that Leo wouldnt allow him to go it=
 alone but as Leo
> > and the others were catching up to him, he takes thin=
gs in stride and slows
> > his sprint down to a lope and then to a trot bef=
ore slowing further to a
> > walk and then stops. Something stops him from =
making a foolish mistake.
> > Instead he transforms into robot mode and nod=
s to his comrades.
> >
> > " Intuition just told me to take a different app=
roach to this situation.
> > Something that only Master Yoketron would do a=
t a time like this. I must
> > remember my training, and why I was chosen t=
o undergo such mentor ship ."
> >
> > He looks to Leo and Big Convoy.
> >
>=
 > " All right, we still have a bit of a way to go by the sound of things, =
and
> > I think a two phased strategy is better than a one shot deal. Since=
 I've
> > been blind for a long time, I can navigate in darkness rather qui=
ckly. It's
> > best you allow me to go ahead and map a way for you to allow=
 easier access
> > and cut down on time expansion. Leo, Big Convoy, I would=
 like the heavier
> > Maximals to follow behind with you, and the Maximals =
who are swift and
> > agility based to follow me. You can chose whoever you=
 deem fits either
> > category. This also holds true for the Predicons assi=
sting in our efforts.
> > We have a greater chance at success if we work st=
rategically."
> 
> <NEW>
> 
> LEO PRIME looked over at BIG CONVOY.
> 
> "Ye=
ah, they are all like this in the begining." CONVOY said. "Young
> and full=
 of confidence." There was a chuckle from CONVOY, "As the
> humans have sai=
d, ten foot tall and bullet proof."
> 
> Looking back at TUSCON there was a=
 nod from LEO PRIME, "Let's go." He
> said as the other MAXIMALS rallied up=
 around them.
> 
> As they moved on the tunnel turned abruptly and showed t=
hem the
> reasoning for the flickering light as the tunnel ended at a ledge=
, a
> ledge that was hundreds of feet from the floor of a vast cavern, the
=
> cieling of which was nearly fifty feet above the top of the tunnel
> they=
 had just emerged from. The cavern stretched out for perhaps a
> mile or mo=
re in diameter and was maybe two or three hundred feet from
> floor to ciel=
ing.
> 
> The cieling itself had large stalactites reaching down perhaps 30=
 feet
> from the cieiling, while there are an equal number of stalagmites
>=
 rising from the floor. There is even a sparse type of fungi-like
> vegatat=
ion down here, although it is different from anything seen on
> the surface=
.
> 
> In the center of the chasm, about a mile away from the tunnel entran=
ce
> there was a large cylinder of yellow light fire rising from the floor
=
> of the cave and disapearing into a hole in the cieling. It
> superficiall=
y looked like fire it also had the look of some sort of
> energy as sparks =
crackled and arced all around it.
> 
> It is this flickering light that was=
 noticable from the tunnel as the
> light itself bathed the cavern.
> 
> At=
 the bottom of the the columb of fire was a large black pit and
> hanging s=
uspended above it by blackened chains was a tiny figure in
> red . . . OPTI=
MUS PRIME who was being bathed in that very fire!
> 
> Although it was diff=
icult to see at nearly a mile distant, the tiny
> figures of MAGMATRON and =
SABERBACK were standing watching. Around them
> were arrayed SHARKTICONS an=
d some others that from that distance
> appeared to be DINOBOTS or at least=
 something akin to them.
> 
> But even at the distance there was a booming =
chuckle that sounded like
> it came from SABERBACK even though he was still=
 merely a mile away!
> 
> (TAG)
> 
> - Preston

<html><head></head><body bgcolor=3D"#FFFFFF"><div>Tucson looks to Optimus a=
s he's bathed in the fire.  Yet, instead of charging in as the others =
would have thought he'd do, Tucson remains put and in a train of quiet thou=
ght.  So much so that he gave such an emotionless gaze as if in deep m=
editation.  Yoketron had taught him not to act in complex situations b=
ut to think instead, of a way to cleverly get around a tough spot.</div><di=
v><br></div><div>He looks at the fungi growing in the cavern, and the stala=
gmites and stalactites and sniffs the moisture rich air around them.</div><=
div><br></div><div>"Water.  It feeds the plants and ground even this f=
ar down.  Fire, as powerful as it is, it yet has one weakness.  A=
nd what gives life to the vegetation, brings death to the flames of fire. &=
nbsp;And even more so of an enemy to flames is the cold earth that is benea=
th our feet.  But we haven't got time to dig, we need water and I sens=
e it, all around us.  If we can access the water we can put out the fi=
re."</div><div><br><br>Don't be envious of what you don't have, be grateful=
 for things you already posses.  Nothing is worth more than family and=
 friends.</div><div><br>On Jan 18, 2012, at 12:26 PM, Super Cyclonus <<a=
 href=3D"mailto:supercyclonus@...">supercyclonus@...</a>> wr=
ote:<br><br></div><div></div><blockquote type=3D"cite"><div>

      <p>> <OLD><br>
><br>
> Tucson had a feelin=
g that Leo wouldnt allow him to go it alone but as Leo<br>
> and the oth=
ers were catching up to him, he takes things in stride and slows<br>
> h=
is sprint down to a lope and then to a trot before slowing further to a<br>=

> walk and then stops.  Something stops him from making a foolish mista=
ke.<br>
> Instead he transforms into robot mode and nods to his comrades=
.<br>
><br>
> " Intuition just told me to take a different approach t=
o this situation.<br>
> Something that only Master Yoketron would do at =
a time like this.  I must<br>
> remember my training, and why I was chos=
en to undergo such mentor ship ."<br>
><br>
> He looks to Leo and Big=
 Convoy.<br>
><br>
> " All right, we still have a bit of a way to go =
by the sound of things, and<br>
> I think a two phased strategy is bette=
r than a one shot deal.  Since I've<br>
> been blind for a long time, I =
can navigate in darkness rather quickly.  It's<br>
> best you allow me t=
o go ahead and map a way for you to allow easier access<br>
> and cut do=
wn on time expansion.  Leo, Big Convoy, I would like the heavier<br>
> M=
aximals to follow behind with you, and the Maximals who are swift and<br>
&=
gt; agility based to follow me.  You can chose whoever you deem fits either=
<br>
> category.  This also holds true for the Predicons assisting in ou=
r efforts.<br>
> We have a greater chance at success if we work strategi=
cally."<br>
<br>
<NEW><br>
<br>
LEO PRIME looked over at BIG CONVOY.<=
br>
<br>
"Yeah, they are all like this in the begining." CONVOY said. "Youn=
g<br>
and full of confidence." There was a chuckle from CONVOY, "As the<br>=

humans have said, ten foot tall and bullet proof."<br>
<br>
Looking back a=
t TUSCON there was a nod from LEO PRIME, "Let's go." He<br>
said as the oth=
er MAXIMALS rallied up around them.<br>
<br>
As they moved on the tunnel tu=
rned abruptly and showed them the<br>
reasoning for the flickering light as=
 the tunnel ended at a ledge, a<br>
ledge that was hundreds of feet from th=
e floor of a vast cavern, the<br>
cieling of which was nearly fifty feet ab=
ove the top of the tunnel<br>
they had just emerged from. The cavern stretc=
hed out for perhaps a<br>
mile or more in diameter and was maybe two or thr=
ee hundred feet from<br>
floor to cieling.<br>
<br>
The cieling itself had =
large stalactites reaching down perhaps 30 feet<br>
from the cieiling, whil=
e there are an equal number of stalagmites<br>
rising from the floor. There=
 is even a sparse type of fungi-like<br>
vegatation down here, although it =
is different from anything seen on<br>
the surface.<br>
<br>
In the center =
of the chasm, about a mile away from the tunnel entrance<br>
there was a la=
rge cylinder of yellow light fire rising from the floor<br>
of the cave and=
 disapearing into a hole in the cieling. It<br>
superficially looked like f=
ire it also had the look of some sort of<br>
energy as sparks crackled and =
arced all around it.<br>
<br>
It is this flickering light that was noticabl=
e from the tunnel as the<br>
light itself bathed the cavern.<br>
<br>
At th=
e bottom of the the columb of fire was a large black pit and<br>
hanging su=
spended above it by blackened chains was a tiny figure in<br>
red . . . OPT=
IMUS PRIME who was being bathed in that very fire!<br>
<br>
Although it was=
 difficult to see at nearly a mile distant, the tiny<br>
figures of MAGMATR=
ON and SABERBACK were standing watching. Around them<br>
were arrayed SHARK=
TICONS and some others that from that distance<br>
appeared to be DINOBOTS =
or at least something akin to them.<br>
<br>
But even at the distance there=
 was a booming chuckle that sounded like<br>
it came from SABERBACK even th=
ough he was still merely a mile away!<br>
